content: @scottmcm Good points. OH, didn't know rust-analyzer supports type-aware queries, I'll check their docs to see if this type of querying is convenient to do, thank you!
Darrow O'Lykos [Rust Philly] has marked this topic as resolved.

For clarity: I'm not familiar with exactly what r-a can do. But that kind of "find usage of this specifically" is the kind of thing that language server implementations (and IDE things in general) are there to do.

But if r-a can't already do it, I bet they're working on it.
Ohkay I see what you mean, thank you for clarifying @scottmcm!

FWIW, it would be easy to write a generic tool to help with this, @Darrow O'Lykos [Rust Philly], should r-a not do it / or not be usable in some context, by using a custom (and potentially runtime-customizable) lint pass, using something like dylint.

(see https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/blob/6206086dd5a83477131094b1f0ef61b10e7ced42/clippy_lints/src/methods/inefficient_to_string.rs#L14-L22 for the implementation of the inefficient_to_string lint, for instance, whose calls roots up to the following visitor / "lint pass": https://github.com/rust-lang/rust-clippy/blob/6206086dd5a83477131094b1f0ef61b10e7ced42/clippy_lints/src/methods/mod.rs#L2181-L2199 )
